INTRODUCTION

Baldwin Directory Company, Inc., publishers of your city directory,

takes pleasure in presenting the 1947 edition to the general public. A

large force of trained enumerators and solicitors worked diligently in the

preparation of this volume and we are confident that the result is an

authentic and useful city directory.

We have faith in the continued growth of your city and we believe

that our directory will take its place as one of the vital instruments for

the advancement of your community. Subsequent editions will be issued

promptly and regularly.

This volume is an example of the ABCD type of city directory as

originated and developed by the Baldwin Directory Company, Inc. In

the modern business world with its greatly changed sales and credit sys-

tems, the old type of directory has become completely obsolete. In adapt-

ing the directory to modern conditions the Baldwin organization is the

pioneer. The excellent city directory which your city now has is the

result of the progressive spirit of this company and its accurate inter-

pretation of modern business requirements.

SIX DIVISIONS OF THE BOOK

The principal parts of the Baldwin Directory are as follows:

1. The Buyers Guide and Civic Section is made up of the adver-

tisements of the leading business firms of the city, announcements of

churches, clubs, lodges, associations and schools, and professional cards

of public-spirited lawyers, physicians and dentists. The display spaces

have been carefully grouped and indexed under headings which are de-

scriptive of the business engaged in by each firm. The Buyers Guide,

when properly arranged and distributed, is of tremendous value in the

building of business in the community.

2. The Resident Directory contains most of the data concerning the

individual. The wifes name is given in parenthesis, and the number of

dependents under 16 is shown as well as the ownership of homes. This

is followed by position, place of employment and home address.

8

INTRODUCTION

3. The Householders Directory contains a complete directory of

streets and avenues, properly located, gives the names of all householders

arranged as they come upon the streets and avenues, indicates ownership

of property.

4. The Business Directory and List of Nationally Advertised Brands

contains the names of all business firms, professional people and non-

profit organizations, properly classified. In this division are also listed

the name of nationally advertised brands of merchandise, with the name

of the local agents or distributors.

5. The Numerical Telephone Directory contains telephone numbers

arranged in numerical sequence.

6. Rural Route Directory contains names of all rural residents.

SPECIAL ABCD FEATURES

The following valuable information which appears in the ABCD type

of directory is not to be found in the old-style city directory:

Number of dependents under sixteen;

Designation of home ownership;

Nationally Advertised Brands;

Numerical Telephone Directory;

Telephone Numbers on Street Guide.

In addition to these valuable features, the ABCD type of directory

is more conservatively styled, printed on better paper and more beauti-

fully bound, arranged for more convenient use and contains a much more

complete civic section. Directory stands are maintained in the business

district for the use of the general public.

THE HOUSEHOLDERS SUPPLEMENT

After including every conceivable feature which would tend to make

the directory as useful and attractive as possible, the originators of the

ABCD type of directory made one more bold strokethey established a

guaranteed HOME circulation for advertising matter by issuing the

Householders Supplement and delivering it to the homes of the commu-

nity. Every advertisement which appears in a Baldwin Directory also

appears in the Householders Supplement, making the Baldwin Directory

Americas greatest dollar-for-dollar advertising medium today.

BALDWIN DIRECTORY CO., INC.

EXPLANATION

All people sixteen years or over are listed.

Wives are listed with husbands, the wife being shown in parenthesis as follows:

Smith Robt R (Mary L).

The number of children under sixteen years is shown after the wifes name as

follows: Smith Robt R (Mary L) 3.

The both in the resident directory and the householders directory designates

ownership of the home.

In case of a natural widow this fact is shown with the name of the deceased

husband in parenthesis, whenever possible, as follows: Smith Mary L (wid Robt R).

The occupation and place of employment are shown as follows: Smith Robert R

(Mary L) elk Hub Clothing Co.

The residence of each person is shown, "h" denoting a householder or head of

the family, r denoting people in the home.

Married women, engaged in home other occupation than housekeeping, are listed

individually in addition to their regular listing with their husbands, as follows: Smith

Mary (Mrs Robt R) bkpr Henry Jones & Co r 210 Main.

Names in heavy type denote patrons of the directory and are usually the leading

firms in each line of business.

Persons living outside the city limits and receiving mail in the country are

marked RD.

The letters BD shown on some entries indicate Buyers Directory.

Colored is shown by a . The publishers are very careful in using this, but do

not assume any responsibility in case of error.

This directory contains all the regular departments of the modem city directory

and many features used by no other publisher in the United States.

A numerical telephone directory will be found in the back of the directory list-

ing each telephone according to number.

The Rural Route Directory will be found in back of this volume.

The classified business directory lists each firm according to line of business.

The numerical street directory lists each street alphabetically and each house

according to number, with the street intersections as they appear. After each house-

holders name will be found his telephone number. In case he has no telephone the

nearest telephone may be found. The denotes householders who own the house

in which they live. By using the street guide as a mailing list, a thorough coverage

of the city will be obtained without any duplication of names.

The buyers guide carries the printed messages of the citys leading business and

professional firms arranged alphabetically according to classifications.

This directory shows the exact population of the city and environs at the present

time.

GEORGIA

AGRICULTURE

Two of the principal sources of income are cotton and poultry and

there are established marketing systems for these commodities. This is

the second largest broiler section in the world. The total broiler business

for the eight county area amounts to over thirty million dollars annually.

Gainesville furnishes the entire Southeast with live and dressed poultry.

The weekly output of baby chicks runs from 200,000 to 800,000. The Poul-

try By-products plant and the Pathological Laboratory are other develop-

ments in this field.

Rural electrification service in Hall County amounts to 299.3 miles

serving 3,258 rural consumers.

The City Ice Company operates one of the largest freezer locker

plants in the State. The Commercial Freezing Room cares for 400,000

pounds. This is mainly for the poultry and dairy industries. There are

1,800 lockers in this plant. 60% of these are used by people in the rural

areas and 40% by the towns people.

EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES

Gainesville offers to its citizens an unusually wide range of educa-

tional opportunities. With four different systems of schools represent-

ing both public and private educational enterprises, educational training

from kindergarten through college may be had within the city.

The Gainesville public school system is composed of six schools with

an enrollment of 1,950 students and 69 teachers. All of the six schools

are recognized by the state accrediting agencies. The Main Street Gram-

mar School was constructed in 1904 and represented the best in public

school buildings when it was built. The Candler Street Grammar School

building was constructed in 1910 and it, likewise, was complete in every

detail when it was constructed. The Candler Street School Annex was con-

structed in 1946 and is modern in every detail.

Both the white and the colored high schools are accredited by the

Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools. Gainesville

High School was constructed in 1920 and is one of the better high school

buildings in the state. The High School Auditorium-Gymnasium Annex

was contructed in 1936 and is the largest auditorium in the city. The

Fair Street High School for colored pupils was constructed in 1936 and

is a valuable and up-to-date building.

Hall County public school system is composed of twenty two schools

for white pupils and nine schools for Negroes. There are approximately

6,000 white pupils instructed by 181 teachers; there are about 360 Negro

pupils instructed by 12 teachers.

12

GAINESVILLE, GEORGIA

Five of the schools of the Hall County public school system are within

the municipal area of the city of Gainesville. Three of these are gram-

mar schools and two are high schools. Chicopee Grammar School is just

south of the city limits in the Chicopee mill village. Gainesville Mill pub-

lic school is on the southeastern edge of the city. New Holland public

school is in the Pacolet mill area on the northeastern side of the city.

River Bend High School is on the northern side of the city and Lyman

Hall High School is on the southern edge of Gainesville municipal area.

The private high schools in Gainesville are represented by Brenau Acad-

emy and Riverside Military Academy.

Brenau Academy is a private boarding school for girls of the high

school level. The academy has a limited enrollment of 125 pupils and

draws its membership from a score of states of the union. It is under

the general administration of Brenau College.

Riverside Military Academy is one of the largest schools of this type

in the country. It admits boys of both grammar school and high school

level and has a total enrollment of about 1,000 students. Riverside Mili-

tary Academy has the unique arrangement of spending the fall and spring

months in Gainesville and the winter quarter in an auxiliary plant at

Hollywood, Florida. Riverside Military Academy buildings and campus

are on the northwestern side of the city of Gainesville.

Brenau College is a non-sectarian, liberal arts college for women and

represents the senior college educational enterprise of the city of Gaines-

ville; Brenau College was founded in 1878. The college campus of 28

acres is in the heart of the city and is located within three blocks of the

main business district. The college plant is composed of thirty academic

and residence buildings. The student body of nearly 500 students is drawn

from 40 of the 48 states and a number of foreign countries. The faculty

and administrative staff numbers about 60 people. The college offers the

A. B. degree and special training in music, dramatics, and liberal art sub-

jects.

The total student population, from grammar school through college,

of all educational institutions in Gainesville and Hall County is something

over 9,550 students. This is a significant indication of the educational

opportunities of the city of Gainesville and its vicinity.

HISTORY

Gainesville was established as the county seat of Hall County by the

General Assembly of Georgia in 1818. The town was laid out March 16,

1820. It was named for General Edmund Pendleton Gaines, whose ex-

ploits aided greatly in the War of 1812 and the town has long been known

as the central trading point of Northeast Georgia.

Hall County was named for Lyman Hall, one of the signers of the

Declaration of Independence from the Colony of Georgia and soon after

the transfer of the Four Mile Purchase strip of land from the Cherokee

Indians in 1818 to the United States government was opened for settle-

ment and early was populated with many of the best families of lower

Georgia, the Carolinas, and Virginia. It is one of Georgias best counties

and with the advantageous position occupied geographically, combined

GAINESVILLE, GEORGIA

13

with the constructive force of an energetic and enterprising citizenship,

has taken the leading place among the counties of North Georgia.

Gainesville is fifty-two miles from Atlanta, on the Southern Railroad

and has an elevation of 1,253 feet above sea level. The Gaines-

ville Midland, a short line railroad connects Gainesville with Athens,

Georgia where the Georgia, Central of Georgia and Seaboard Railroads

afford excellent freight facilities. Another branch of the Midland con-

nects at Monroe, Georgia, with the Green County Railroad and the Geor-

gia Railroad, thus affording outlets to the Atlantic coast. Cotton has been

the principal crop but during the past decade, poultry has surpassed cot-

ton as the main money crop. Productive soil, moderate climate, and good

rainfall have contributed to the growth of all kinds of agricultural crops

known in the north temperate zone.

During the horse and buggy days, Gainesville was known all over

the South as a health resort. Many valuable mineral springs are located

nearby and for several generations, the hotels and springs were visited by

many low country people who came North during the summer for their

health.

Gainesville has a mining and an agricultural back country. At one

time, the post office department distributed mail through this office to

over one hundred post offices. All departments of trade are represented,

but Gainesvilles great attraction to strangers is its incomparable climate,

pure water, quality of citizenry, church-going and law abiding people and

hospitable homes. After the railroads were built, the cotton mills soon

followed. The industrial growth began about the turn of the century and

other interests were attracted to the city. With the large back country

north of Gainesville having no railroad, various wholesale interests were

developed and have helped to make this section more prosperous.

Along with industrial development, then came educational institu-

tions like Brenau College for young women, and Riverside Academy for

boys and many parents came with their children to these schools and

found profitable business attractions.

Again, climatic conditions proved most helpful. The following table

of statistics as furnished by the U. S. Dept, of Agriculture will prove

helpful to anyone looking for a pleasant place to live.

The normal annual mean temperature is 59.3 degrees.

The normal annual average rainfall is 54.87 inches.

The normal spring temperature is 59.2 degrees.

The normal summer temperature is 76.2 degrees.

The normal autumn temperature is 60.3 degrees.

The normal winter temperature is 41.5 degrees.

14

GAINESVILLE, GEORGIA

INDUSTRY

The history of any industry is to a large degree a personal story of

the leadership of the enterprise, but Gainesville and her varied industries

do not allow us space to go into the personal nature of each industry.

' From the very beginning of the industrial life of Gainesville, the

sound policies of its leaders have directed its activities in the realm of in-

dustrial, civic, social and religious life.

The sound judgment of the pioneers in selecting Gainesville for new

enterprises has been fully justified. Today there are over 8,000 persons

working in the varied industries of the town. The policies of the differ-

ent types of industry have been to give to all employees the opportunity

to have good homes, a clean environment, high ranking schools, whole-

some development and an opportunity for saving through earnings. The

business value of such policies has proved to be sound, as shown by divi-

dends on original investment.

One of the outstanding characteristics of industry in Gainesville is

the intimate knowledge its leaders have of the industrial and community

needs, a complete understanding of the employees needs and the coopera-

tion in making these conditions the best possible, and in meeting all de-

mands of progress in an intelligent manner. These facts signify the truth

that Gainesville industry has a deep concern for the human factor in In-

dustry and that the human element through the years has shown an in-

spiring response to this interest.

CREDIT BUREAUS

...and the greatest of these is

A message to parents and educators on the

Seed of Character-Forming as a Part

Of Every Childs Training

CHARACTER, Capacity and Capital are the three standards

by which business men judge applicants for credit. And

CHARACTER comes first.

For, a man may have Capitalplenty of money. He may have

Capacitythe ability to earn money. But without Character,

the willingness to pay promptly according to agreementhis

promises are worthless. The man with character can be de-

pended upon to keep his promises and meet his obligations.

Character is a childs heritage, strengthened by the example

of the parent and the precept of the teacher during early years;

the formative period.

Character is honora high sense of personal responsibility

and respect for ones obligations. And every child has the

right to be trained in the tenets of honesty and fairness in

meeting his obligations. Otherwise his education is incom-

plete; his chance for success is impaired.

FOR A GREATER GAI1SVILLE

The 38 employes of the Georgia Power Company in Gainesville

are at your service. They are willing workers and proud citi-

zens who are anxious to provide Gainesville with electric service

that is second to none.

The following information will help you get the best possi-

ble service:

The Gainesville District Office of the Georgia Power

Company is at 137 East Washington Street. Here is

where you may pay your electric bills, make service

applications, buy electrical appliances and bulbs. At

this office you may arrange for a visit by a home

service representative, a rural engineer, a lighting

engineer or an industrial power engineer. The tele-

phone numbers are 136 and 137.

The Companys Service Building is at 409 Oak Street.

Here small electrical appliances may be brought for

repairs. If a large electrical appliance is in need of

repair, telephone 1083 and ask for Appliance Repair.

A repairman will be sent to your address.

To report trouble with your electric service, call 1083

and ask for the Trouble Department.
